what: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
text: v0.2 | [Documentation] R interface Lazy Cartesian Products. Provides memory-efficient ways obtain elements (including random samples) Cartesian Products. Partial wrapper lazy-cartesian-product C++ library (Burdsall, 2018).

title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
text: Suppose need random sample 1,000 elements Cartesian Product 125M elements. rlazycartesian can without generating elements advance (expand.grid() ). makes operation fast consumes little RAM—see Benchmarks .
code: library(rlazycartesian)  l <- list(x = paste0("x", 1:500, sep = ""),           y = paste0("y", 1:500, sep = ""),           z = paste0("z", 1:500, sep = ""))  lc <- lazy_cartesian(l) lc #> `lazy_cartesian` object with 1.25e+08 elements set.seed(1) head(get_random_sample(lc, 1000)) #>   .element    x    y    z #> 1 66608964 x267 y218 z464 #> 2 44492929 x178 y486 z429 #> 3 60941821 x244 y384 z321 #> 4 30845227 x124 y191 z227 #> 5 17633234  x71 y267 z234 #> 6 79310131 x318 y121 z131

what: A note on element indices and expand.grid()
title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
text: Element indices rlazycartesian equivalent indices sorted expand.grid():
code: get_elements(lc, c(12345, 98765)) #>   .element  x    y    z #> 1    12345 x1  y25 z345 #> 2    98765 x1 y198 z265  eg <- expand.grid(l) eg <- eg[order(eg$x, eg$y, eg$z),] rownames(eg) <- NULL eg[c(12345, 98765),] #>        x    y    z #> 12345 x1  y25 z345 #> 98765 x1 y198 z265

title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
text: random sample example , compare performance (Elapsed_Time_sec) peak RAM usage (Peak_RAM_Used_MiB):
code: peakRAM::peakRAM(   {lc <- lazy_cartesian(l); get_random_sample(lc, 1000)},   {eg <- expand.grid(l); eg[sample(1:nrow(eg), 1000),]} ) #>                                       Function_Call Elapsed_Time_sec #> 1 {lc<-lazy_cartesian(l)get_random_sample(lc,1000)}            0.002 #> 2  {eg<-expand.grid(l)eg[sample(1:nrow(eg),1000),]}            4.332 #>   Total_RAM_Used_MiB Peak_RAM_Used_MiB #> 1                  0               0.2 #> 2                  0            2862.1

title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products
text: Starting v0.2, rlazycartesian supports simple restrictions Cartesian product. example, suppose following Cartesian product want exclude elements “Red” “Circle,” well elements “Square” numbers 1 3:
code: l <- list(color  = c("Red", "Blue", "Yellow"),           shape  = c("Square", "Circle"),           number = 1:3)  r <- list(   restriction1 = list(color = "Red", shape = "Circle"),   restriction2 = list(shape = "Square", number = c(1, 3)) )  lc <- lazy_cartesian(l, restrictions = r) lc #> `lazy_cartesian` object with 9 elements (after restrictions) #>   => 2 restrictions excluded 50% of the Cartesian Product  #>      (which originally had 18 elements) get_random_sample(lc, 9) # (note element indices still go up to 18) #>   .element  color  shape number #> 1       17 Yellow Circle      2 #> 2       16 Yellow Circle      1 #> 3        8   Blue Square      2 #> 4       18 Yellow Circle      3 #> 5       10   Blue Circle      1 #> 6       12   Blue Circle      3 #> 7       14 Yellow Square      2 #> 8       11   Blue Circle      2 #> 9        2    Red Square      2

title: R Interface for Lazy Cartesian Products

what: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
title: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
text: function lazily retrieves elements Cartesian product, given vector indices.

title: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
text: lc lazy_cartesian object, created rlazycartesian::lazy_cartesian(). indices numeric vector indices elements retrieve. index_colname string column name indices output data frame. default, ".element".

title: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
text: data frame row element Cartesian product.

title: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
text: Burdsall, T. (2018). lazy-cartesian-product: .hpp library efficiently generate combinations using Lazy Cartesian Product algorithm. https://github.com/tylerburdsall/lazy-cartesian-product

title: Lazily retrieve elements from a Cartesian product — get_elements
code: l <- list(color  = c("Red", "Blue", "Yellow"),           shape  = c("Square", "Circle"),           number = 1:3)  r <- list(   restriction1 = list(color = "Red", shape = "Circle"),   restriction2 = list(shape = "Square", number = c(1, 3)) )  lc <- lazy_cartesian(l, r) get_elements(lc, c(2, 8)) #>   .element color  shape number #> 1        2   Red Square      2 #> 2        8  Blue Square      2

title: Lazily get random sample from a Cartesian product — get_random_sample
Lazily get random sample from a Cartesian product — get_random_sample
text: lc lazy_cartesian object, created rlazycartesian::lazy_cartesian(). n_sample integer number elements sampled. index_colname string column name indices output data frame. default, ".element".

title: Lazily get random sample from a Cartesian product — get_random_sample
text: data frame row element (potentially restricted) Cartesian product. Indices first column correspond unrestricted Cartesian product (.e., go 1 n_ur).

title: Lazily get random sample from a Cartesian product — get_random_sample
text: Burdsall, T. (2018). lazy-cartesian-product: .hpp library efficiently generate combinations using Lazy Cartesian Product algorithm. https://github.com/tylerburdsall/lazy-cartesian-product

title: Lazily get random sample from a Cartesian product — get_random_sample
code: l <- list(color  = c("Red", "Blue", "Yellow"),           shape  = c("Square", "Circle"),           number = 1:3)            lc <- lazy_cartesian(l)  get_random_sample(lc, 3L) #>   .element  color  shape number #> 1       13 Yellow Square      1 #> 2       12   Blue Circle      3 #> 3       15 Yellow Square      3

title: Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
text: function creates lazy_cartesian object, possible restrictions.

title: Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
text: l named list combinations Cartesian product. restrictions list lists restrictions. Defaults NULL. See Examples .

title: Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
text: lazy_cartesian object.

title: Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
text: Burdsall, T. (2018). lazy-cartesian-product: .hpp library efficiently generate combinations using Lazy Cartesian Product algorithm. https://github.com/tylerburdsall/lazy-cartesian-product

title: Create a lazy_cartesian object — lazy_cartesian
code: l <- list(color  = c("Red", "Blue", "Yellow"),           shape  = c("Square", "Circle"),           number = 1:3)  r <- list(   restriction1 = list(color = "Red", shape = "Circle"),   restriction2 = list(shape = "Square", number = c(1, 3)) )  lc_without_restrictions <- lazy_cartesian(l) lc_without_restrictions #> `lazy_cartesian` object with 18 elements  lc_with_restrictions <- lazy_cartesian(l, r) lc_with_restrictions #> `lazy_cartesian` object with 9 elements (after restrictions) #>   => 2 restrictions excluded 50% of the Cartesian Product  #>      (which originally had 18 elements)

what: Impose a restriction to a Cartesian product — restrict
title: Impose a restriction to a Cartesian product — restrict
text: internal function imposes restriction Cartesian product

title: Impose a restriction to a Cartesian product — restrict
Impose a restriction to a Cartesian product — restrict
text: l named list combinations Cartesian product. restriction named list forms restriction. name element variable. value element value values variable. Multiple elements joined via `&`. v_each vector times variable's values repeated.  See `rlazycartesian:::restrict_multi()`.

what: Impose multiple restrictions to a Cartesian product — restrict_multi
title: Impose multiple restrictions to a Cartesian product — restrict_multi
text: internal function imposes multiple restrictions    Cartesian product. See `rlazycartesian:::restrict()`.

title: Impose multiple restrictions to a Cartesian product — restrict_multi
Impose multiple restrictions to a Cartesian product — restrict_multi
text: l named list combinations Cartesian product. restrictions named list restrictions. See `restrict_multi()`.
